results: The Great Gatsby is a remarkable novel about the Jazz Age - primarily about Jay Gatsby and his pursuit of Daisy Buchanan, but also about the extravagant lifestyle of the wealthy, the disillusionment of the American Dream, and the emptiness of materialism. F. Scott Fitzgerald has crafted a masterful work about his own experiences and observations of the Roaring Twenties. The novel is captivating, evocative, and thought-provoking. It made me reflect on my own aspirations, relationships,

Text: The Thing About My Folks is a wonderful film about relationships - first and foremost an adult son and his father, but also that son with his wife, his sisters and his mother. Paul Reiser has written a semi-autobiographical movie about his relationship with his father. The movie is funny, poignant and thought-provoking. It led me to re-evaluate my own relationship with both my now-deceased father and my adult son. Peter Falk is excellent as Paul's father - the role could not have been better cast. I hope that both Mr. Falk and Mr. Reiser are recognized in next year's movie awards for their efforts - Falk for his performance and Reiser for his script.

results: Overall a highly disappointing film. The build-up to the main storyline is painfully slow. The character of Maria Schrader searching for her family's hidden past lacks depth and feels clichéd. The constant switching between present-day New York and 1940s Berlin is confusing and there is no clear indication of the time period. The worst part is the ending, where the film suggests that the Jews were freed from their torment by a bureaucratic accident. The question of who actually liberated them is never answered,

Text: Overall an extremely disappointing picture. Very, very slow build up to the basic storyline. The role of Maria Schrader searching for her families secret past. (Every take seems to last forever. There is really no rhythm in the film.) ***SPOILERS*** Her Mother Ruth is rescued from the Nazis, by a German woman, played by Katja Riemann. The entire character of Ruth is so one dimensional, so stereotypical. ***SPOILERS END*** The film cuts back and forth between present day New York and Berlin and Berlin 40s something. Please when you do that, give the audience an indication of what time exactly the story takes place. There is never a clear indication of time  very annoying. Worst part is, the end. ***SPOILERS*** The entire show and jabber about the Jews being so terribly tormented, simply by a bureaucratic accident! Give me a break. That's how the Jews got out of the Rosenstrasse? The question of who freed the Jews is NEVER answered. Was is Goebels who freed them? Did Lean Fischer sleep with Goebels? In Venice the film won an acting award for K. Riemann, why?  I have no idea. Must be the Jewish theme

Text:

prediction: Overall a highly disappointing film. The build-up to the main storyline is painfully slow. The character of Maria Schrader searching for her family's hidden past lacks depth and feels clichéd. The constant switching between present-day New York and 1940s Berlin is confusing and there is no clear indication of the time period. The worst part is the ending, where the film suggests that the Jews were freed from their torment by a bureaucratic accident. The question of who actually liberated them is never answered,
